occurrences.line_text: Some of deare louers, foes perpetuall:
Those two were foes the fellonest on ground,
Still watcht on euery side, of secret foes affrayd.
So mortall foes so friendly to agree,
And deadly foes so faithfully affrended,
That mortall foes doe turne to faithfull frends,
So did these two through all the field their foes enforce.
And on their foes did worke full cruell wracke:
Of litle much, of foes she maketh frends,
Both girlonds of his Saints against their foes offence.
Then his foes loue or liking entertaine:
And raging flames, that many foes shall reare,
Of both her foes had seene, and now her frends
Where when they saw their foes dead out of doubt,
The malice of her foes, which her enuy,
And euen to her foes her mercies multiply.
Maugre so many foes, which did withstand.
Yet when as foes enforst, or friends sought ayde,
Her to defend against all forrein foes,
Though many foes did him maligne therefore,
There his three foes shrowded in guilefull shade,
So did that Squire his foes disperse, and driue asonder.
Him well behoued so; for his three foes
Mongst many foes, him selfe did faster hye;
To fight with many foes about him ment,
Maintaine this euill vse, thy foes thereby to foile.
Amongst so many foes, whom sure he thought
Fearelesse of foes that mote his peace molest;
Fearelesse of foes, or fortunes wrackfull yre,
To firends, to foes, which skill men call Ciuility.
That terrifide his foes, and armed him,
When suddeinly a grosse fog ouer spred
Like the faire Morning clad in misty fog did shew.
Like as the Moone in foggie winters night,
To sparke out litle beames, like starres in foggie night.
A foggy mist, that ouercast the day,
A foggy mist had couered all the land;
His blushing face in foggy cloud implyes,
When foggy mistes, or cloudy tempests haue
As when a foggy mist hath ouercast
And golden foile all ouer them displaid,
Maintaine this euill vse, thy foes thereby to foile.
Which there were slaine, as sheepe out of the fold,
Shall he thy sins vp in his knowledge fold,
Till he his armes about her sides gan fold,
Eft to Cymochles twise so many fold:
And more deformed Monsters thousand fold,
Great heapes of them, like sheepe in narrow fold,
After her flocke she in their fold had tyde,
And euery euening helping them to fold:
With folded hands and knees full lowly bent
Purfled vpon with many a folded plight,
His double folded necke she reard vpright,
His huge long tayle wound vp in hundred foldes,
Through all those foldes the steelehead passage wrought
The heardes out of their foldes were loosed quight,
About her cursed head, whose folds displaid
In many folds, and mortall sting implyes.
That to the folds, where sheepe at night doe seat,
As he had beene a fole of Pegasus his kind.
Of these poore folk, whose soules with black dishonor
Thus flocked all the folke him round about,
Whom all that folke with such contention,
Of th'inland folke, which sought him backe to driue,
For Chian folke to pourtraict beauties Queene,
Which late her folke had slaine, she bad the[m] forth to hold.
So sounded the retraite, and drew his folke away.
Wayting what tydings of her folke became.
In wich the names of all loues folke were fyled,
To which folke-mote they all with one consent,
And humid euening ill for sicke folkes cace:
By which fraile youth is oft to follie led,
And made him selfe thensample of his follie.
Full of vaine follies, and new fanglenesse:
Deserues to tast his follies fruit, repented payne.
Their wanton follies, and light meriment;
Her dalliance he despisd, and follies did forsake.
Wrought with wilde Antickes, which their follies playd,
So on him selfe to wreake his follies owne despight.
He ment to make them know their follies prise,
To wrecke on them their follies hardyment:
And had receiu'd their follies worthy hire,
So thought the Souldan in his follies threat,
Of him, for all his former follies meed,
But loe the Gods, that mortall follies vew,
And to great ones such follies doe forgiue,
I gan my follies to my selfe to plaine,
But still did follow one vnto the end,
That him to follow was but fruitlesse paine;
To follow her, that was the causer of their ill.
Might fall on her, and follow all the way,
Full many mischiefes follow cruell VVrath;
Shall follow you. So passing forth she him obaid.
Whom all the people follow with great glee,
Could not for sorrow follow him so fast;
Inueigled him to follow her desires vnmeete.
And now is fled; foule shame him follow, where he went.
Inflamed was to follow beauties chace,
Did follow that ensample, which he blam'd afore.
But giue me leaue to follow mine emprise.
He gan auize to follow him no more,
Would not so lightly follow beauties chace,
Through which he follow should his brethren bad,
For thy, the bloudy tract they follow fast,
That Ladies all may follow her ensample dead.
We both are bound to follow heauens beheasts,
Did all the way him follow hard behind,
Forst him eftsoones to follow other game,
I follow here the footing of thy feete,
To follow that, which he did long propound;
To follow his aduentures first intent,
To follow his old quest, the which him forth did call.
He ran still on, thinking to follow fast
Yet still he him did follow euerywhere,
Can follow out those false footsteps of his,
To thinke to follow him, that was so swift and light.
To follow him; for he was swift in chace.
But Calidore did follow him so fast,
To follow his first quest, when as he spyde
And passed forth, to follow his first enterprise.
And follow through the world, where so he went,
And store of cares doth follow riches store.
To follow sheepe, and shepheards base attire:
Who now does follow the foule Blatant Beast,
Whilest Calidore does follow that faire Mayd,
And yet his feare did follow him behynd:
There follow'd fast at hand two wicked Hags,
Yet he her followd still with courage keene,
And all the way him followd on the strand,
Ne followd on so fast, but rather sought
Fiercely they followd on their bolde emprize,
And follow'd them, in mind her to haue reau'd
Long so she fled, and so he follow'd long;
And follow'd fast: but when he came in sight,
At last when long he follow'd had in vaine,
She follow'd her, and thought againe it to assay.
Them follow'd fast, and them reuiled sore,
Him follow'd Yar, soft washing Norwitch wall,
Which when his Ladie saw, she follow'd fast,
His bands, and follow'd him with gladfull glee,
As they were follow'd of their former feare.
Where so he fled, he followd him apace:
But follow'd fast the Monster in his flight:
Through woods and hils he follow'd him so fast,
Yet by the cry he follow'd, and pursewed fast.
Which follow'd her, with cursed hands vncleane
Him follow'd, by the tract of his outragious spoile.
Him through all Faery land he follow'd so,
As if his feare still followed him behind;
Yet she still followed her former stile,
Him followed eke Sir Guyon euermore,
Long followed, but not fond.
And full of fiery zeale, him followed long,
Faire Britomart so long him followed,
And followed was of him likewise full fast;
He foot by foot him followed alway,
He followed fast, and chaced him so nie,
And like a fearefull dog him followed through the land.
The same she followes, till at last she has
But followes her farre off, ne ought he feares,
And followes other game and venery:
Yet feare them followes still, where so they beene,
She comes vnsought, and shonned followes eke.
So sore him scourgeth, that the bloud downe followeth.
With all her band was following the chace,
With forced fury following his behest,
Whose footsteps Bladud following in arts
Following the guidaunce of her blinded guest,
But firmely following her first intent,
And following Dee, which Britons long ygone
That following his chace in dewy morne,
He following that faire aduantage fast,
In following of him, that fled so fast,
But with his whip him following behynd,
And when he felt the folly of his Lord,
A foe of folly and immodest toy,
Bablers of folly, and blazers of crime.
Nath'lesse to thee thy folly I forgiue,
But often did my folly fowle reproue.
And folly seem'd to leaue the thing vndonne,
But soone he gan such folly to forthinke againe.
To attribute their folly vnto fate,
I will a while with his first folly beare,
They haue the price of their owne folly payd.
With foltring tong, and trembling euery vaine,
And foltring tongue at last these words seemd forth to shake.
With lips full pale and foltring tongue opprest,
His foltring toung with pangs of drerinesse,
But chaufd and fom'd, with courage fierce and sterne,
The yron rowels into frothy fome he bit.
That their broad flaggie finnes no fome did reare,
That filleth all the sea with fome, diuydes
Doth frie with fome aboue the surges hore.
That he gan fret and fome out bloudy gore,
That through his fiercenesse fomed all with sweat,
His steed was bloudy red, and fomed ire,
Was drawne vpon the waues, that fomed him around.
That fomed all about his bloody iawes.
Faint friends when they fall out, most cruell fomen bee.
His angry steede did chide his foming bitt,
Then foming tarre, their bridles they would champe,
That wont in charet chace the foming Bore;
Where foming wrath, their cruell tuskes they whet,
Chaufing and foming choler each against his fo.
Foming with poyson round about her gils,
And with her brest breaking the fomy waue,
Came rushing in the fomy waues enrold,
His fomy steed, whose fierie feete did burne
Along the margent of the fomy shore,
Then gan he freshly pricke his fomy steed,
Along the fomy waues driuing his finny droue.
And flame with gold, but the white fomy creame,
That Venus of the fomy sea was bred;
And fond, that ioyest in the woe thou hast,
Where thee a Ploughman all vnweeting fond,
Which whenas true by tryall he out fond,
The fond encheason, that me hither led.
With deadly rancour he enraunged fond,
Shall by to morrow by thy side be fond.
Her ferry brought, where him she byding fond,
But fairely tempring fond desire subdewd,
Are mortall men so fond and vndiscreet,
His robbed whelpes, and at the last them fond
So goodly purpose they together fond,
Th'off-spring of Elues and Faries there he fond,
The reach of men, through flight into fond mischief fell.
Foolish delights and fond abusions,
That all in peeces it was broken fond,
Of her fond fauorites so nam'd amis:
Great hazard were it, and aduenture fond,
Which whenas none she fond, with easie shift,
And many straunge aduentures to be fond,
Out of her daughters hart fond fancies to reuerse.
Of her miscarriage should in her be fond,
Where meeting with this Redcrosse knight, she fond
Long followed, but not fond.
Fond Proteus, father of false prophecis,
And they more fond, that credit to thee giue,
Without fell rancor, or fond gealosie;
For in the sea to drowne her selfe she fond,
And shamefully reproued for his rudenesse fond.
Fond is the feare, that findes no remedie;
To sea[r]ch her forth, where so she might be fond,
Vnquiet Care, and fond Vnthriftihead,
Albee in heart he like affection fond,
Fond knight (sayd she) the thing that with this eye
And such fond fauours sparingly dispenst:
Fond Squire, full angry then sayd Paridell,
Ne euer was with fond affection moued,
That bore three such, three such not to be fond;
And sayd, Fond dame that deem'st of things diuine
Therefore this Fay I hold but fond and vaine,
But by his friend himselfe eke soone he fond,
At which he wondred much, when all those signes he fond.
Feigning full many a fond excuse to prate,
False Labyrinthes, fond runners eyes to daze;
With whom great feast and goodly glee he fond,
So fond a lesson, as to loue againe.
Such was this Ladies fit, in her loues fond accusing.
Each rowme she sought, but them all empty fond:
And therefore ought it haue, where euer she it fond.
The better to beguile, whom she so fond did finde.
Why then will ye, fond Dame, attempted bee
Ne wote I surely, whether her he yet haue fond.
I fonder, then Cephisus foolish child,
I fonder loue a shade, the bodie farre exild.
Or to allure such fondlings, whom she trayned
Sometimes her head she fondly would aguize
They were faire Ladies, till they fondly striu'd
Great labour fondly hast thou hent in hand,
Thereat th'old man did nought but fondly grin,
Himselfe in thousand peeces fondly rent,
That ye were runne so fondly far astray,
Into the hands of his accursed fone,
Ne euer may be vsed by his fone,
He fought great battels with his saluage fone;
Of his Norueyses, to assist the Britons fone.
Gainst all those knights, as their professed fone,
She came of her accord, in spight of all his fone.
At Scudamour, both his professed fone.
So Marinell by him was rescu'd from his fone.
Defend thee from the vengeance of thy fone,
With which she vsed still to tye her fone;
And asked her, what were those two her fone,
For whom they wayted as his mortall fone,
How many of their friends were slaine, how many fone.
BON FONT: but bon that once had written bin,
Hurles forth his thundring dart with deadly food,
And deadly food he makes: him to offend
And doen the heauens afford him vitall food?
Lo here I now for want of food doe dye:
For want of food, and sleepe, which two vpbeare,
But feed on shadowes, whiles I die for food,
Good both for earthly med'cine, and for heauenly food.
Of her chaste bodie, nor with commune food,
To her for bread, and yeeld her liuing food:
Right fit to rend the food, on which he fared.
For other food then that wilde forrest beares,
Of food, which in her duresse she had found:
Their pleasant friskes, and loath their wonted food;
He might not with immortall food be fed,
Ne dayly food did take, ne nightly sleepe,
In her owne mouth the food, ment for her chyld,
Therefore they mote not taste of fleshly food,
Arryuing, to his kyne for food assynd;
Crying for food, did greatly him offend.
Had for his food late gathered from the tree,
The fields my food, my flocke my rayment breed;
For your meane food shall be my daily feast,
Scarse yeelding her due food, or timely rest,
Fruitfull of all things fit for liuing foode,
But roughly him bespake. Thou fearefull foole,
Foole (said the Pagan) I thy gift defye,
Enough to hold a foole in vaine delight:
For sure a foole I do him firmely hold,
And prou'd himselfe most foole, in what he seem'd most wise.
Whom she did put to death, deceiued like a foole.
And a lewd foole her leading thorough dry and wet.
Led by a Carle and foole, which by her side did passe.
That he could make; And eeke that angry foole
But that same foole, which most increast her paines,
Ne ought that foole for pitty did him spare,
With that the foole, which did that end awayte,
The whiles the foole did him reuile and flout,
To pitty him that list to play the foole:
That huge great foole oppressing th'other Knight,
To ioy at his foole-happie ouersight:
One mother, when as her foolehardie chyld
And reason with foole-hardize ouer ran;
Had vsed bene of that foolehardy Squire;
Apes, Lions, ï¿½/-gles, Owles, fooles, louers, children, Dames.
Yet was admired much of fooles, women, and boys.
But vsd to fish for fooles on the dry shore,
For courting fooles, that curtesies would faine,
For wisedome is most riches; fooles therefore
T'entrap vnwary fooles in their eternall bales.
But the third time shall rew his foolhardise:
Least thy foolhardize worke thy sad confusion.
At last the Nourse in her foolhardy wit
Foolhardy as th'Earthes children, the which made
The foolish man, that pitties all this while
O foolish faeries sonne, what furie mad
So oft as he through his owne foolish pride,
Thee, foolish man, so rash a doome to giue?
O foolish men, why haste ye to your owne decay?
But that the foolish man, fild with delight
To feede her foolish humour, and vaine iolliment.
Foolish old man, said then the Pagan wroth,
That mad or foolish seemd: one by his vew
Foolish delights and fond abusions,
Through foolish pitty, then her guilefull bayt
That now we foolish men that prayse gin eke t'enuy.
I fonder, then Cephisus foolish child,
O foolish Physick, and vnfruitfull paine,
But foolish boy, what bootes thy seruice bace
He comes not here, we scorne his foolish ioy,
Foolish Narcisse, that likes the watry shore,
At last turning her feare to foolish wrath,
His foolish maladie, and long time had misled.
Saying, Thou foolish knight, that weenst with words
And in their foolish fancie feigne thee blind,
Laught at his foolish labour spent in waste;
The foolish man thereat woxe wondrous blith,
The whiles her foolish garde, that little knew
Both foolish knights, I can but laugh at both,
That hauing cast him in a foolish trance,
Too foolish Paridell, that fayrest floure
Like foolish flies about an hony crocke,
The foolish Kyte, led with licentious will,
But foolish Mayd, whyles heedlesse of the hooke,
Was crackt in twaine, but by his foolish feere
Thou foolishe Elfe (said then the Gyant wroth)
To ferry that old man ouer the perlous foord.
Foreby a narrow foord, to them well knowne,
That headlesse him into the foord he sent:
Ne wist which way he through the foord mote pas.
The which themselues prepard thorough the foord to ride.
Through that same perillous foord with better heede,
Whom he did ouerthrow by yonder foord,
And foorth they passe, with pleasure forward led,
He hath his shield redeem'd, and foorth his sword he drawes.
She stayd, and foorth Duessa gan proceede,
Peepes foorth, and soone renewes her natiue pride;
Lookt foorth, as Phoebus face out of the east,
So foorth they went, and both together giusted;
Bring foorth an infinite increase, that breedes
The whiles his life ran foorth in bloudie streame,
Yet wisedome warnes, whilest foot is in the gate,
That hand or foot to stirre he stroue in vaine:
Vnder the steepe foot of a mountaine hore;
Vnder his Lordly foot him proudly hath supprest.
Where neuer foot of liuing wight did tread,
Where entred in, his foot could find no flore,
Vnder the foot of Rauran mossy hore,
Thrise he assayd it from his foot to draw,
The other foot, fast fixed on his shield,
And kist the ground, whereon his foot was pight;
And fairely fare on foot, how euer loth;
So forth he far'd, as now befell, on foot,
His Palmer now shall foot no more alone:
And rushed in on foot to ayd her, ere she dyde.
Streight at his foot in base humilitee,
Tract of his foot: then dead through great affright
Dismay with feare, or cause one foot to flie,
The whiles on foot was forced for to yeed,
To thinke, such hideous puissaunce on foot to beare.
On foot with him to matchen equall fight;
He ran on foot, as if in lucklesse warre
Wanting his sword, when he on foot should fight:
Cymochles twise, that twise him forst his foot reuoke.
And both as swift on foot, as chased Stags;
His foot thereon, may neuer it recure,
Ne did the other backe his foot returne,
With her on foot, and stoutly forward came;
Ne euer to them yielded foot of ground
Ay ioyning foot to foot, and side to side,
Ay ioyning foot to foot, and side to side,
Ne foot could further moue: the Lady gent
And forst t'alight, on foot mote algates fare,
Vnable to arise, or foot or hand to styre.
She struggled strongly both with foot and hand,
Downe to her foot, with carelesse modestee.
She fastned hath her foot, which standes so hy,
On foot, vpon the face of liuing land?
Whose hideous tayle his left foot did enfold,
Was with the force nigh feld whilst his right foot did slyde.
Could stand on foot, now to renew the fight.
Whiles with long fight on foot he breathlesse was,
Himselfe by them on foot, to succour them from feare.
With easie steps so soft as foot could stryde.
The Prince on foot, not wonted so to fare;
Hence fare on foot, till he an horse haue gayned.
Doth not your handmayds life at your foot lie?
For neither will one foot, till we that carle haue hent.
That foot of man might sound the bottome plaine,
And ere he could recouer foot againe,
But saue my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.
Fighting on foot, as well he him descryde,
Standing alone on foot, in foule array:
To driue you so on foot vnfit to tread,
But forst to trot on foot, and foule misused,
Where foot of liuing creature neuer troade,
Them wont to weare, and wend on foot for need,
He could no path nor tract of foot descry,
He foot by foot him followed alway,
He foot by foot him followed alway,
Ne would the Prince him euer foot forsake,
His foot he set on his vile necke, in signe
Had traueld still on foot in heauie armes,
Which tosseth states, and vnder foot doth tread
No foote to foe. The flashing fier flies
A vile disease, and eke in foote and hand
And bound him hand and foote with yron chains.
Then on his brest his victour foote he thrust:
And treading vnder foote her honest name:
Fast bounden hand and foote with cords of wire,
Like as a Goshauke, that in foote doth beare
And Priamond on foote had more delight,
But horse and foote knew Diamond to wield:
And that he should not long on foote endure,
And to alight on foote her algates did compell.
Ne yeelded foote, ne once abacke did flit,
Past forth on foote, beholding all the way
Vnder my foote let each lay downe his sword,
Her proud foote setting, at his head did leuell,
Whom when he saw before his foote prostrated,
One foote was set vppon the Crocodile,
That the bold Prince was forced foote to giue
And gan him selfe to fight on foote prepare.
In these strange waies, where neuer foote did vse,
Both hand and foote vnto a tree was bound:
To proue if better foote then horsebacke would ensew.
Who was more light of foote and swift in chace,
In trauelling on foote so long a space,
Not wont on foote with heauy armes to trace,
That hardly passable on foote it was:
So fare on foote till thou another gayne,
And for thine owne defence on foote alight,
He goth on foote all armed by her side,
Endure to trauell, nor one foote to frame:
To moue one foote, but there must make abode;
When his foote slipt (that slip he dearely rewd,)
He in his necke had set his foote with fell disdaine.
And least he should recouer foote againe,
That euery foote did tremble, which did tread,
And at the foote thereof, a gentle flud
With footing worne, and leading inward farre:
The forward footing for an hidden shade:
In which the tract of peoples footing was,
A damzell spyde slow footing her before,
Scarse could he footing find in that fowle way,
For as he forward moou'd his footing old,
Halfe flying, and halfe footing in his hast,
That no'te without an hound fine footing trace.
Or by what meanes may I his footing tract?
Ne had they footing found at last perdie,
Went forth in hast, and did her footing trace
Enforced them their forward footing to reuoke.
I follow here the footing of thy feete,
Stood still a while, and his fast footing kept,
